course_name: SILK ROADS AND SPICE ROUTES: ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL ASIA AND WORLD CONTACTS
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course will investigate the economic, political, religious, cultural, and technological impact of long distance land and sea trade between Asia and other world religions in ancient and medieval times up to around 1500.

course_name: WAR AND MEMORY IN MODERN EAST ASIA
prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'HISTORY 1601E', 'isLink': True}, {'text': 'and 1.0 History course numbered 2200 or above; or 2.0 History courses numbered 2200 or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: The course analyzes the effects of five crucial wars fought during the period of 1840-1953 in East Asia, especially those of the excesses committed by the dominant armies. It also provides the students with an opportunity to study various interpretations of the events and reflect on war, war crimes, and collective memories.

course_name: SEX, LAW, AND SOCIETY IN IMPERIAL CHINA
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200-level or above or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course examines state regulation of sexuality in imperial China as manifested in the official treatment of adultery, rape, female chastity, prostitution, and violation of social taboos. It also investigates the life of people excluded from accepted patterns of marriage and family.

course_name: HISTORY OF WOMEN AND GENDER RELATIONS IN AFRICA
prerequisites_text: [{'text': "2.0 courses in History or Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies, taken at the 2200 level or above if they are History courses or at the 2000 level or above if they are Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies courses.", 'isLink': False}]
description: In the past African women were powerful leaders, strong economic contributors and respected members of their extended families. This course will examine these historical roles as well as factors that undermined African women's status and changed gender relations, such as slavery, economic forces and colonialism.

course_name: FOREIGN RELATIONS OF THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course will examine the foreign relations of the People’s Republic of China from its inception in 1949 through to the present day. The focus of the course will be on China’s political and security relations with global powers, including the Soviet Union/Russian Federation, Japan, India, Iran, and the USA.

course_name: RESISTANCE TO APARTHEID IN SOUTH AFRICAN AND GLOBAL HISTORY
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 course in History at the 2200-level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: In this course, we will read, research, and write about structural and quotidian racism in colonial Southern Africa in the 20th century. Concomitantly, we will study the resistance movements and their leadership skills in antiracist work locally and globally. Herein is potential to change lives and futures.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200-level or above or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This seminar will examine major themes of European Imperialism.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 course at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course analyses and compares a variety of themes which have been important in the development of both Canadian and American society. It also examines the involved and often difficult relationship of Canada and the United States, with an emphasis on the patterns of political, social, economic and military interaction.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'Two courses in History or Political Science at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course examines environmental issues in Canada and the United through biography, focusing on leadership by individuals and groups in historical context. Issues include changing ideas of nature, conservation of renewable resources, preservation of habitats, air and water pollution, energy projects, and human health/environmental justice.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: Topics include: the relationship between humans and their environment; ideas on conservation and the environment; the science of ecology; and the history of the conservationist and environmental movements.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 senior history courses at the 2200-level or above, or permission of the Department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course is a comparative history of Italian Fascism, Nazism and Stalinism. Topics include Marxism and fascism as ideologies, the cultural and social roots of communist and fascist movements, the seizure of power, church-state relations, racial bio-politics, war and political violence, ethnic cleansing, resistance, and authoritarian legacies.

course_name: HISTORIES OF THE CIRCUMPOLAR NORTHS: 'THE LAST IMAGINARY PLACES'
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course examines the circumpolar Norths -  Alaska, Kalaallit Nunaat, Nunavut, Siberia, Saami homelands and more. These regions have long been coveted by resource-hungry southerners and home to "Northerners", Indigenous and otherwise. Coverage includes indigenous lives, southern imperialism, and how various Norths were conceived and re-conceived in the South.

course_name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY EXPERIENCE
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
antirequisites_text: [{'text': 'HISTORY 4710F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': ',', 'isLink': False}, {'text': 'HISTORY 4711F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': ',', 'isLink': False}, {'text': 'HISTORY 4712F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': '.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This research-intensive course provides an examination of selected aspects of the First World War in various combatant nations. Among the themes to be discussed are the alliance system, the experience of battle, home-front conflicts, war culture, gender, strategic and tactical decision-making, and the memory of the war.

course_name: THE WORLD WARS IN HISTORY, MEMORY AND RECONCILIATION
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 History course at the 2200-level or above, and permission of the Department. (Please note, because of the limited enrolment and special circumstances of international travel associated with this course, students will also be interviewed before their registration is finalized.).', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course, which concludes with a 10-day program in Belgium and France, explores commemorative practices that emerged after the World Wars. Topics include the presentation of history through monumental architecture, the preservation of battlefields, and museums, and how these sites have informed identity and efforts to reconcile former enemies.
extra_info: 3 hours. Additional cost to be borne by students. Limited enrollment. Application and interview are required. Cross-listed with History 3710F/G.

course_name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY EXPERIENCE
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course provides an examination of selected aspects of the First World War in various combatant nations. Among the themes to be discussed are the alliance system, the experience of battle, home-front conflicts, war culture, gender, strategic and tactical decision-making, and the memory of the war.

course_name: THE FIRST WORLD WAR: A REVOLUTIONARY RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'HISTORY 4711F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': '.', 'isLink': False}]
description: Students will work individually on an extended research project in the history of the First World War. Themes include engaging with primary documents, presenting research in a conference setting, preparing for publication, and identifying other opportunities for the dissemination of research.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 History course at the 2200-level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course explores the popular Spiritualist movement of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, which held that life continued after bodily death and that the spirits of departed souls could be contacted by trained mediums during seances. What certainties did spiritualists hope to discover, and what frauds did their detractors unmask?

description: Seminar. Selected topics in the history of Amerindian-white relations.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200-level or above or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course will introduce students to gender theory generally and masculinity theory specifically. It will also survey critical debates in the history of masculinities while dealing with major themes in modern history.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: A seminar course that examines selected topics to explore the social construction of gender and sexuality in nineteenth and twentieth-century Canada and America.

course_name: MURDER: A SOCIAL AND LEGAL HISTORY
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200-level or above or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: What makes murder a crime? This course explores the legal evolution of murder and of the adversarial murder trial.  Each week students examine a different type of murder - infanticide, domestic murder, serial killings - using coroners’ records, trial transcripts, police files, popular broadsides, newspaper reports, and other relevant primary sources.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 history courses at the 2200 level or above.  Year 3 or 4 Honours Specialization History or Honours Double Major History, or permission of the Department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: Selected topics in the history of warfare.
extra_info: 3 hours. This course may be counted as a principal course in the Honours Political Science program. Restricted to Honours Students.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 History courses at the 2200-level or above, or 2.0 Indigenous Studies courses at the 2000-level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course will critically examine archival sciences relating to Indigenous peoples. Long perceived as politically neutral, the collection of records is now identified as an act of settler-colonialism that displaces Indigenous peoples and their historical practices. A class project, alongside relevant case studies, considers themes of power, intersectionality, and reconciliation.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 History course at the 2200-level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course places students with agencies and organizations in the community in order to complement classroom learning with experienced-based knowledge of how influence is exercised in public life. Students will work to satisfy both specified learning objectives and placement job requirements.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This seminar course examines the social impact of the automobile and automotive technology from the late nineteenth century to the present. Technology, industrial design, corporate management styles and the rise of popular automotive culture are among the topics to be examined.

course_name: MAKING HISTORY MATTER TO THE PUBLIC: PRACTICING ACTIVE HISTORY
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '2.0 courses in History at the 2200 level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course explores the ideas, historiography and practice of active history, an historiographical practice that is responsive to communities of study, the discussion of the work of historians among public audiences. The course examines key themes and the work of prominent historians who have modeled a practice of Active History.
This project-based studio course is a research capstone for students in the History of the Book module.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'Registration in any academic program at the second-year level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
antirequisites_text: [{'text': 'DIGIHUM 2130A/B', 'isLink': True}, {'text': ',', 'isLink': False}, {'text': 'DIGIHUM 3902F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': ',', 'isLink': False}, {'text': 'the former History 2816A/B.', 'isLink': False}]
description: In this course students will learn how historical content is produced, presented and published online; how to find and evaluate digital primary and secondary sources; and how to use computational techniques to work with digital resources. No previous background in the subject area is required.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 History course at the 2200-level or above.', 'isLink': False}]
description: An introduction to close reading and how historians can use the techniques of structured intelligence analysis. Working individually and in groups, students will analyze a series of historical case studies from the 20th and 21st centuries. Topics include espionage, cyber war, terrorism, organized crime, homeland security, counterintelligence, and decision support.

course_name: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION AND HUMAN RIGHTS
prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 course in History at the 2200-level or above, or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course explores human rights history, focussing on the language and practice of rights in the French Revolution. Students examine the foundational rights texts of the revolutionary era, and the expansion, limitation, denial of rights for women, religious minorities and people of African origins, enslaved and free, in colonial contexts.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': '1.0 course in History at the 2200-level or above, or permission of the department.', 'isLink': False}]
description: This course explores the roots of the contemporary human rights movement in the era of Nazism-Fascism and the Holocaust, from the interwar period to the decades after 1945 and the development of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Topics include the role of faithbased organizations as advocates for human rights.

extra_info: 2 lecture hours. This course is meant to complement the course Classical Studies 2700A/B: Technology and Engineering in the Ancient World.

description: A general historical survey of ideas in the physical and biological sciences from antiquity to the twentieth century. This course will also examine issues in scientific methodology as well as the impact of scientific ideas on society.

course_name: INTRODUCTION TO THE HISTORY OF MEDICINE
description: An overview of the development of medicine from antiquity to the present, including the growth of medical sciences, concepts of disease, therapies, and the history of medical practice and institutions.

course_name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN THE HISTORY OF MEDICINE
prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'One course in History of Science, or permission of the Department.', 'isLink': False}]

Introduction to the history, mission, and philosophy of the Human Ecology/Home Economics professions in North America and the evolving concepts of Human Ecology/Home Economics as a field of study in higher education. Socialization toward professionalism will include the development of knowledge, skills and values appropriate to the profession.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'Registration in the Foods and Nutrition or Nutrition and Families modules (Honours Specialization, Specialization, Major).', 'isLink': False}]
description: A social-psychological analysis of communication theory in the context of interpersonal small-group and large-group dynamics. Group exercises to improve communication skills and to stimulate discussion. Assignments and laboratories to provide an opportunity to prepare and present information within the scope of foods and nutrition and human ecology.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'HUMANECO 2222A/B', 'isLink': True}, {'text': 'or the former Human Ecology 2222F/G.', 'isLink': False}]
description: A survey of both visual and functional aspects of the design of shelter, furnishings, clothing and consumer products. Physical needs, social/psychological factors, as well as technology, environmental, ethical and economic concerns will be addressed.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'HUMANECO 2222A/B', 'isLink': True}, {'text': 'or the former Human Ecology 2222F/G.', 'isLink': False}]
description: A study of the economic and ethical principles in housing needs of individuals and families and how those have been met at different times in history, in different societies and particularly today in Canada, including discussions of housing design, urban planning, environmental issues and alternative housing.

precorequisites_text: [{'text': 'Pre-or Corequisite(s):', 'isLink': False}, {'text': 'HUMANECO 2222A/B', 'isLink': True}, {'text': '.', 'isLink': False}]
description: An interdisciplinary approach to the study of the roles and responsibilities of consumer, marketer, and government in the market-place. Emphasis on consumer behavior and management of human, economic, and environmental resources.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'BUSINESS 1220E', 'isLink': True}, {'text': '.  Registration in the Foods and Nutrition modules (Honours Specialization, Specialization, Major).', 'isLink': False}]
description: An introductory study of management principles, evolution of theories and influence of the behavioral sciences on current management practice. Functions of management, assessment and development of managerial skills. Case studies to help develop analytical and decision-making skills.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'HUMANECO 4411F/G', 'isLink': True}, {'text': '. Registration in the Foods and Nutrition modules (Honours Specialization).', 'isLink': False}]
description: Extra Information: Minimum of 10 tutorial/laboratory/field work hours.Limited enrolment course.

prerequisites_text: [{'text': 'Registration in the Foods and Nutrition modules (Honours Specialization).', 'isLink': False}]
description: Students will study the components of research and develop a research proposal.

This course is a preliminary exploration of the interdisciplinary field of Human Rights Studies that examines historical and contemporary human rights and their impact on people’s lives around the world. Topics include legal and religious conceptions of rights, debates over rights,  and their practical applications in law, policy and workplaces.

This course examines the historical development and philosophical foundations of human rights, and the efficacy of legal, diplomatic and political frameworks designed to protect human rights. Topics include women’s rights; the rights of minorities; refugees and displaced persons; remedies for human rights violations in domestic and international law.

This course explores the historical and political context in which Human Rights are recognized as a discourse in Canadian society. It examines the complexity of human rights and the contradictory forces which have led to successes and failures in protecting minorities in this country.
Half-term course dealing with selected topics in Human Rights. Topic and course description will be available at time of registration.
Half-term course dealing with selected topics in Human Rights. Topic and course description will be available at time of registration.
